{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3647825,"name":"Kalimul","username":"Kalimul","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/a6a055/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-07T04:19:30.823Z","cooked":"

Hi, I’m from Team 694 Stuypulse. This year for our pose estimation we used two LL4s and placed them on the front and back sides of our robot to have the most accurate pose during alignment to the reef. However we noticed that, if our cameras don’t see a tag, we have a bad pose estimate from just our wheel odometry. We’re using the generated swerve code from CTRE, which handles the odometry calculations. We’ve sanity checked constants (wheel diameter, gear ratio) many times and can confirm they are correct.

A few weeks ago, we tested our odometry by running our PID to pose with our cameras disabled. We positioned the robot at the same starting point each time and drove straight forward at varying distances (5, 10, and 15 ft). The robot stops driving when it thinks it is within tolerance of its setpoint; we reduced this tolerance to one inch for ease of testing and accounted for it during our calculations.

Moreover, we reran these tests at two different max velocities and accelerations (in the PID to pose we motion profile the translational and rotational vel/accel setpoints). We noticed that the odometry data was significantly better at the lower numbers than the higher ones, which makes sense to us (higher speed and acceleration leads to more wheel slip = bad wheel odometry).

Then we compared the actual distance traveled with the expected, desired distance. In general, our odometry undershoots all the time, and the error worsens at a higher speed and acceleration.

How can we improve our odometry? What are some factors that we may not be accounting for, or things we may be doing wrong? Here’s a link to our robot code on Github: GitHub - StuyPulse/Aunt-Mary: StuyPulse 2025 Robot Code, and here’s the PID to pose implementation: Aunt-Mary/src/main/java/com/stuypulse/robot/commands/swerve/pidToPose/SwerveDrivePIDToPose.java at main · StuyPulse/Aunt-Mary · GitHub

Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

What swerve module are you using in what gear ratio? And what is the frame size?

If it was always low I’d really consider decreasing your wheel diameter.

You said you checked wheel diameter, but what is your process for that. Do you measure it directly or do you run other tests to determine it?

For example, we will run a fixed distance at the higher end of speed/accel without slip and compare and adjust wheel diameter from that.

At higher accels avoiding wheel slip seems hard.

+1 on the wheel radius. For our old-school 4" SDS aluminum billet wheels and neoprene tread running on Neyland II carpet, our odometry calibrates best using a 1.90" radius for new tread and 1.89" for pretty worn tread. That’s a 5% odometry error if using a nominal 2" radius. Fixing this would not help a wheel slip problem at high acceleration, but it may take care of much of the inaccuracy you are seeing.

We used a caliper to measure the wheel diameter, although now that I think about it the value might have been slightly less than what we have in code. I’ll check at our next meeting and update how it goes

Calibrate your wheel radius by measured driving on carpet or using a spin-in-place characterization routine. The way your tread interacts with the carpet is critical and is going to be poorly estimated by calipers. With calipers, there is also the question of how hard you squeeze the flexible tread and how you position the edges of the jaws against the tread texture.
